My favourite place to be in the Arab Street/Bali Lane area. The whole vibe is super chilled out and borderline hippie-ish, but a rastafari feel is prevalent as well. Think lots of plants, pretty lights and helpful but laid back service staff.My favourite place to sit is outside because it's great for people watching. They set up tables along the street (like most places in the district do) and you've got your choice of spots if you go early enough. What really adds to the laid back feel of Om is that there is no menu. This also ensures that the staff are knowledgeable enough to know everything on the menu, their prices and their discounts. And the prices are pretty cheap too: Beer (Asahi, Heinken, usual beer options) Liquor (Gin, Vodka, Tequila, Rum, Whiskey) + mixed (free)Cocktails ($12 onwards)Shisha ($25) If you head upstairs, and you'll have to take your shoes off, there's a cosy little attic which is really good for functions. Spread yourselves out on the floor amidst carpets and cushions, and order plenty of drinks - a bucket of beer is $40 which is great for a group or that one alcoholic friend we all have. Definitely one of the coolest places in Arab Street simply because it doesn't try.

This place was one of the first few Cafes that opened at Haji Lane - and it still has a nice buzz of people always hanging out, drinking, etc. The ambiance is very chill-out, and the place has a feel - with cushions on the floor, pictures and paintings on the wall, very friendly staff, and the guys that own this place, Barry & Oli are really nice and sweet guys.What I Love: There's always some activity going on, be it fire juggling, tarot card readings, musicians performing. There are small events, very underground and rave-like, that happen occasionally. The vibe's very underground, creative, artistic and hipster-ish. The second floor is my fave, basic & chill-out, great to hold tiny gatherings. Their food portions are pretty big and the wedges are yummmyyyyy.What I Don't Love: Their drinks. Their finger food is okay. But drinks-wise, stick to bottled or canned beverages.

Fuck. Yes.If you're looking for damn good shisha or an eclectic community of accordionists, fire eaters, musicians and artists  - this is the place to look. Grab a double apple hookah and enjoy the crowd.
Hippie type place, very rare and very refreshing in sometimes too homogenous Singapore. Great music and terrace ambiance on weekend nights !

Came in for a coffee. The experience is not only the drinks and a place to char with friends but the whole ambience. How apt "the gift of life is the present". The whole setup reminded me about my meditation experience. Quiet, peace, the present, equanimity. It is a good getaway from the busy city life.

This is one of the shisha joints that I frequent most along the Haji Lane belt. Compared to the other shisha joints such as Nasrin or Narbins, Going Om is so much more tastefully decorated, with their quirky prints and fascinating looking furniture. Apart from the typical shisha custom mixes such as Apple-Mint, Grape etc, they have a surprise in store for you. If you ask the staff nicely, they whip up a mean "Vodka-infused" shisha. Their shisha is smooth on the throat, and is one of the best I've had in Singapore. Ofcourse, comparing it to the shisha joints in Egypt will not be a fair comparison. Don't bother requesting for a menu, just ask the staff to recommend something for you. Their fried oyster mushroom nibblets were pretty good, and so are their wedges. They offer both alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages too.

A hidden gem in the midst of our bustling city, Going Om is a Cafe Bar with great ambience and a heart - literally! A large, colourful heart is mounted on the hand-painted exterior of the two-storey refurbished shophouse, making it impossible to miss. In the day, it is a calm and peaceful oasis where lush, tropical plants and exotic eastern meditation music welcome weary shoppers seeking respite from the heat. Crystal healing, yoga classes, intuitive card readings and free meditation sessions are some of the unusual additional services offered here.At night, the place is transformed and the atmosphere is almost carnival. People from all walks of life converge here. There are live acoustic performances every night, and a roving magician makes an appearance to entertain and befuddle guests on Thursdays. A real treat is when the Starlight Alchemy movement artists make their weekly appearances. They perform with enchanting lights along the entire length and breadth of the narrow little street, delighting all the customers seated along the street. There is a large variety of flavoured tobacco for shisha, and you can request for custom mixes. However, I have not seen their innovative Watermelon Shisha anywhere else in Singapore. There is no menu here. While the usual western-styled food and bar snacks are available, the owners at Going Om also whip up their own original creations, so expect new dishes every time you head down. The staples fresh salads with homemade dressings and homemade desserts, such as the "Strawberry Surprise" and the "Apple & Pear Crumble", are popular dishes here.The Going Om Chakra drinks are also a must try here. The seven flavours correspond with the seven chakra or energy points in our bodies. They have both alcoholic and non-alcoholic versions.

I want to like this place, because they've got a good groove going with the music. But when they take 45mins to bring you your shisha, that's kinda a deal breaker. We checked on our shisha and tried to cancel after 30mins, only to have it delivered 15mins after cancellation. Even trying to pay the bill was a nightmare. I want to like this place but c'mon guys, help me!

Adore this place. From it's deep fried mushroom salad to juices to shisha to the washroom. Absolutely a place to chill out if you are trying shisha for the first time. I had my first there and had never a bad experience. There was one evening the owner came out with a bottle of maple whiskey for us to try. Epic stuff. Thanks for being so chill and nameste to all.

This is a great place to go to if you want a chill and fun night out in Haji Lane. There are tons of places here in Haji Lane with shisha and drinks but Going Om is probably one of the best places to go to.There is an outdoor and upstairs attic to sit in and both are really relaxed and causal. They have an array of cocktails and beers and you can get a bucket for $40. Sisha here is really good, they have lots of flavors and my favorite is apple mint. The staff here is super friendly and very nice. The place has a really chill and artistic vibe.

Excellent wine choices. Food menu is small, main focus being shared plates. We tried a range of items and found the starters and savoury tarts very very good. We found the Iberico pork and grilled octopus dishes overdone. Otherwise service and food quality very good. Will visit again.

Simple food menus but pretty divine food. Definitely go for the cheese plus meat board...  creme brûlée was a must too.  The wine was good too although they ran out of the Aussie ones.  We will happily go back.

Its a simple cosy restaurant opened by a Chinese couple who employed a few chefs from China. They serve really good, affordable and rather szechuan-flavoured dishes. I don't know whether you'd call it authentic or not but it definitely feels more szechuan than local. They serve this interesting ma ti shui with carrots and corn in it. You can request to eat the stuff in this. Szechuan dishes are generally heavier on spiciness and saltiness. However, this restaurant has cut down on saltiness to suit our Singaporean local taste buds yet the customer could still taste the China flavour in it. Great service you can expect too. I recommend a try!

Great Lebanese food! We were walking around the mosque, and found this restaurant. We had a sample platter (5 different dishes), lavash (bread) and falafel (best of all). This was a fresh discovery in Singapore. While we were enjoying the food there, this is completely different. Also the coffee and desserts are decent enough. One of my favorites in Sings so far.

Tasty food but terrible service. We ordered lime juice but were sent lemonade. When we complained, the waiter was confrontational and said that lemonade and lime juice is the same thing. We ordered Mussaka but were given meat balls. When the mussaka arrived there was no rice. This restaurant has a good Chef but they need to train their waiting staff.

Good service, good food and ambience.  What more can you ask for really?  Only issue with this place is as per any restaurant in this area - parking which can get rather frustrating circulating and increasing your carbon footprint.  We had 3 antipasta i.e the octopus, asparagus and the burratina  and they were all wonderful.  Octopus nicely grilled and well seasoned with a wonderful charr. asparagus simple yet tasting the freshness of it and of course the creamy burrata.  The pastas were also wonderfully done al dente and tasted wonderful.  We finished off with wonderful desserts tiramisu (not the best) and profiterole.  So really a unpretentious place for a nice simple Italian as long u come early - 5:30pm for the parking.   Mar 28th '18Back again.  Glad to report food & service as good as ever the only issue again was the parking.  The shark parking summon people just circling waiting to strike at you :).  Now what is really surprising is the napoleon pizza is even better than the one we had in Napoli!!!

Based on rave reviews about the brick-oven pizza, I finally got a chance to visit Cicheti. You should definitely call to make a reservation, which can get difficult if you're looking to come at a peak time on the weekends.I came with a friend and shared a Pollo (almond pesto chicken) Pizza as well as a Squid Ink pasta (with crab meat). Both dishes were excellent, well-portioned and a great combination for sharing. I would say that the only thing to make the dinner more excellent is if the Pizza had been hotter when it was served. I've been to restaurants where the brick oven pizza is so fresh that it hurts to hold it in my hand (ie: Alt Pizza at Suntec). For a party of 2 on a Friday night, the bill came out to just over $60 including 10% service charge and GST. Not bad, but considering how busy this place seems to get over the weekends, I think I still prefer to go to Alt for my Pizza!

Came here for my sister's bday dinner but she left disappointed. We had chosen to dine at cicheti because she wanted to satisfy her craving of having squid ink pasta and google proved aforementioned restaurant to have one of the better squid ink dishes. Our family got the pulpo and burratina to share as appetizers. The pulpo was way too salty and over cooked - it was really tough. The burratina was 'weak,' for lack of a better word - it was hardly even creamy and more watery than anything. As our mains, we got 2 seafood stews (which tasted decent), a Bismark pizza and the tonnareli nero. My mom complained that the pizza was way overpriced since it came with such basic ingredients. And for the pasta, it was too salty for my sister's liking. She returned it back to the kitchen and the chefs willingly cooked up another portion for her - but it still came out salty the 2nd time around. Maybe the water used to boil the pasta was way over salted? Maybe the pasta itself was made too salty in the kitchen because it's supposedly homemade? I don't know...The kitchen kindly gave us a complimentary dessert (chocolate cake) to make up for all the problems so that was nice of them. But overall, it wasn't a very satisfying meal. We wouldn't come back.

Real food. Period. This is one of the best Italian restaurants in Singapore, as told by many before me. They have a wood-fired oven that makes the pizza really authentic and just so fresh. Everything we've ordered was excellent. I'm a huge fan of those places where their integrity in food shows through from the bread they serve on the side -- they were so well-baked to be crips on the surface and textured just right on the inside. I've had the prawns (4/5) for appetizer -- again very fresh and loved the bread on the side. (good food just don't require much words.) Carbonara pizza (5/5)--excellent, excellent, excellent. I definitely would agree that pizzas are Cicheti's greatest strength. Despite the misconception that carbonara is some creamy, alfredo-like saucy anything, this was an authentic carbonara creation with egg in the middle with caramelized onion that complemented the rich pizza so well. Gnocchi (3/5) on the other hand, was a bit dull. It was good, but not to the standard that was shown through with pizza and the appetizer. I really liked the ricotta bits that were dropped on gnocchi but that was about it. Nothing spectacular. Panna cotta (5/5) -- THE best I've had in Singapore. Generous portion of really well-made panna cottaChocolate fondant (2/5) -- disappointing. Just overly sweet without much sophistication. Would not recommend. Service was okay. I've been told that I wouldn't be able to grab a seat as a walk-in that easily. So I did make the reservation. However, they really need to work on the speed. I am not talking about the slowness in general (as I do understand that good food can take some time) but the interval at which they brought us our food just left us in a very awkward eating & stopping cycle that did not create a good meal experience.All in all, pizza was super impressive and I loved the restaurant. Will definitely be back.

A very cozy restaurant serving Italian food located in the city. I noticed that they have a traditional woodfire oven but we didn't order any of the pizza. Instead, we ordered their daily specials, vongole and roasted veal. The vongoles was nicely cooked with white wine and garlic (not spaghetti), fresh and fragrant. And the veal was perfectly cooked at medium rare paired with Brussels sprouts and bacon. My friend and I love this dish. Price wise, the final bill was $80. Not really cheap but considered the food quality and the good service, worth it. Next time, I will try their pasta and pizza.

If you're craving authentic Italian pizza from a wood fire oven, Cicheti will be your place. This cosy spot has an unassuming shop front on Kandahar St and you could even pass by it if you're not looking for the shop number. Once you enter, you're transported into some (fancy) hole in the wall Italian spot with some legit offerings.I had the margherita bufala, and after looking at all the Yelp photos post-meal, I realised it's a very popular choice! As bufala mozzarella is a soft cheese, it did make the pizza slightly watery, but the tomato sauce and chewy, slightly charred crust made up for it. Not sure if I was just hungry or if it was just THAT good, but I was able to eat the entire pizza myself. I noticed other people were splitting their pies, haha.

I was ecstatic to find this little gem in a country where truly great non-Asian cuisine is hard to come by. I've had the pleasure of trying the pizza, the clam pasta, as well as the prawn starter plate, and all the dishes exceeded my expectations. Absolutely delicious and the staff is friendly to boot. Unfortunately, this doesn't cut it as a 5 stars only because of the wait/reservation system. As one other reviewer noted, even when making a reservation, they basically say you have to be out of the restaurant by a certain time and make it a point to re-emphasize the fact while you're there. While this might be a cultural norm in Singapore, I find that incredibly off putting. It's like, hey, I'm a paying customer too. But I'll be back, because their pizza is bomb.com

Why didn't I know this place earlier? This is to me, a perfect Saturdate venue for a new couple trying out good food! The ambience is warm, inviting yet casual.  We had Polpo, the grilled octopus tail as a starter and it tastes delicious. It is a special menu for the day, thus look out for it! We ordered the Margarita Bulfala as I see that many people have ordered and raved about it. I like the fact that is a stone fired oven pizza. It is also fun to watch the Chef making the dough and putting the pizza toppings. Lastly, we had the squid ink tagliatelle with crab meats. It is actually tomato sauce, not black squid ink sauce, just so you know what to expect. Service was good. Nothing to complain about. There is a good selection of red and white wine. No draught beer though. I will be back for sure!
The best pizza of Singapore. Consistently. Small venue, too bad they are closed on Sunday...

I absolutely adore this place! I came here as one of the first guests last year right after it opened and I immediately felt in love with it and so did my friends whom I invited afterwards. This place is great in every single aspect you can think of. The location in the Arab Street is very convenient, the ambiance is very friendly, staff is super friendly and polite and the food is just awesome! I can highly recommend their pizzas. It is great to come here with a group of friends and order various items from the menu to be shared. The prices are very reasonable and as such it is a great choice!

Really good wood oven pizza and in all honesty even better than where the pizza chef used to work (** have tp find out yourself )  the little dishes are just ok.! love the decor of this little place too. recommended.

Very nice cozy place with amazing food. Every dish was great! Pizzas fresh from the oven, pasta homemade and al dente.. the beef cheek ravioli (?) with truffle was amazing! And you know a restaurant is doing things right when a person who doesn't eat octopus (me) actually loved their octopus. Surprisingly soft and tender, very well done!

The decor and ambiance is outstanding. High quality, but not overdone. Very comfortable, antique style with a few outdoor tables.Food is also top notch. One of the best Neapolitan style pizzas I've had (and I've had many, it's an obsession of mine). I had the bufala margarita, the dough was perfectly cooked in the wood fired oven, which is visible and also adds to the ambiance.

Superb quality pizzas! They have the oven and definitely the chef to impress everyone who goes there for a meal. Food is reasonably priced, and the menu is long enough to order any quality Italian dish. Don't forget to order the chocolate lava cake for dessert! Its outstanding

As far as pizza goes, I don't think there is another choice here. This is my second visit.  Last visit left a very good impression, esp. the pizza so we decided to venture back for some good crust which is such a rarity on this island before heading to the Projector for some german films.  We had the burratina and the bismark and they were as good as I remember - the burratina was fresh, and I'm not just talking about the cheese but the arugula as well which is such a pleasant surprise.  There were too many times when I had not-so-fresh salads here.  The other thing I find restaurants tend to do here is being too generous with the dressing or perhaps it's reflective of local preference but I definitely prefer my salad fresh and with just a tinge of olive oil and/or vinegar, which Cicheti has executed perfectly.  The figs were delightful as i love the fruit and adds some interesting texture and flavor.  Now the pizza came fresh from the oven and I still love the crust - right thickness, right amount of chewiness.  I will definitely recommend this place if you are looking for some authentic pizza.The place seems quite busy and we were lucky getting a seat walking in.  We sat at the patio, which I didn't know about.  It's a fairly small area with three small high tables but quite atmospheric sitting in the open air and munching the dough while listening to the call to prayer.  Service was friendly and efficient.  Also just a stone-throw from all the action around hajilane or if you like movies, the projector across beach road.  Perfect starting point to a good night out.

Was a bit disappointed because I arrived too late for dinner last night as they were closing at 10pm  (after finding them on Yelp) and was craving Italian but the Manager/Part owner was nice and asked me to come back the next day and showed me their menu so I would know what I'm coming back for I decided to come back for lunch and was glad I did!  They remembered me and advised the manager I was here. They allowed me to order off the dinner menu at lunch (thank you for that!) and thank god. yummy!!!Im having salad and gnocchi and it's definitely filling and perfectly seasoned. When I'm back in Singapore I will be definitely coming back for more!  Fresh. Tasty. Great service. It's a 5!

We ordered calamari and roasted asparagus for appetizer.  The calamari was too heavily breaded but the asparagus, while pricy ($11) for four stalks, was delicious. The cioppino that I ordered arrived piping hot. The broth flavorful, full of rich seafood flavor. The tomato base did not overwhelm the flavor.  The fresh calamari, clam, and jumbo prawns were fresh and succulent.  One of the better cioppino I've had. The ambience is good although the pizza oven tends to smoke up the restaurant, causing our eyes to water and become irritated by the end of the night. Overall, a very nice neighborhood restaurant that serves up a wonderful selection of Italian food.

Soooo much love this place. BUT better make a reservation if you want to eat here because it is very popular! Could not get same day reservations for Thursday but secured a reservation for a Saturday night. Cicheti is located near Arab Street and parking can be a challenge.Since we were driving, arrived early to find parking on the street. Bought parking passes at 7-11. There is a covered parking over at Landmark Hotel if you cannot find parking on the street. The restaurant is a rustic but sophisticated dining room that has both upstairs and downstairs seating. Enjoyed dining downstairs much better since that's where all the cooking and action takes place. Plus it had a cool vibe to it. Music was cool as well...kind of a Buddha Bar Euro sound.Uncomfortable Seating alert! I am kind of a skinny minnie (it's "all about the bass" they say) so I don't have a bass for the stool I sat on. It hurt my rear really bad. Bring a pillow to sit on if you are here more than an hour. Service was terrific. Our waiter was really welcoming and very helpful. Our water glasses were always full. To start, ordered the pumpkin salad. It was excellent. Pumpkin was perfectly seared and greens were fresh, fresh, fresh!Next was the spaghetti with New Zealand clams. Sad to say, that dish was a thumbs down. Clams were just too sandy. Would never order this dish again.Of course, the star of the show, and the reason we were here, was the wood fire pizza. . We ordered the Bismark...And it was brilliant! I will definitely will return for the pizza for sure. Oh, and I will bring a pad to sit on. Those chairs are the worst..

Came here for lunch with a friend who lives in the neighborhood. I had been craving wood oven pizza and she said recommended Cicheti. We ordered 2 pizzas - Bismark and Carbonara. The former is a favorite of other reviewers and the latter was recommended by the waitress. The Carbonara totally blew us away. We absolutely loved the caramelized onions that formed part of the topping and we soacked up all the egg yolk with our leftover crust. Perfection! We were sad that the pizzas got cold after awhile. We shared the salted chocolate cake for dessert. Fantastic choice!! I am a big fan of molten lava cakes in general and this one did not disappoint. The portion is quite big - perfect for 2 ladies to share. The melted chocolate oozed out once we dug in. There was just the right amount of salt added to boost the flavor, and the generous scoop of vanilla gelato accompanied with crumbles complemented it perfectly. Heaven in a mouthful! Only gripe is that the kitchen is small so once the place hits capacity service can potentially get slow. Hopefully they have more help for peak hours.

So close to a five-star review, so close. My finger hovered over the mouse clicker for what felt like an eternity before I clicked on four. I may yet change my mind... nah, probably not. Gotta be tough sometimes, know what I'm sayin'?Anyway, the food and potential of this place is straight up five stars. The pizza is fantastic, and most probably my new favourite pizza in Singapore beating out previous faves Extra Virgin and Limoncello. The pasta also is simply wonderful: proper al dente, hand-made especially for the restaurant (according to front-of-house) with a delicately put-together sauce (the pappardelle ragu in this case) and no scrimping on quality ingredients.Moreover the price point is really quite brilliant. Approx. $70 for two pastas and a pizza. I'm not saying it's a steal but given the trend of skyrocketing prices these days, it's pretty damn great. The pizzas themselves are under $20 which is already cheaper than the two previous favourites I mentioned.What let this place down are some details. Firstly, the pizza came out incredibly quickly and was lukewarm. I suspect it was prepared earlier for another patron. The fact that I still rate it so highly is a testament to its overall quality but the misstep still deserves mention.The other letdown was the service. It wasn't terrible. Front of house (a European chap) served us the entire time. He was affable and fairly attentive. But i walked in at 8pm hoping to secure a table and was told that none were available until 9pm. I saw several free, assumed they were booked, agreed to come back for 9 and requested a call should any table free up earlier.My request was rebuffed. I was told that the restaurant was "short-staffed" and that front of house simply did not have time to check his reservations. This is not good enough. Staff your restaurant properly. When I returned at ten to nine, sure enough, the same tables that were available earlier were still empty. Something tells me no one ever ended up taking them and I could have well eaten earlier. This lack of attention and care for your customer is disappointing.The moral of this story: book ahead at Cicheti and accept some arrogance - the place is clearly buzzy right now. But the quality of the food is well worth turning a blind eye to the flaws.

Good service, good food and ambience.  What more can you ask for really?  Only issue with this place is as per any restaurant in this area - parking which can get rather frustrating circulating and increasing your carbon footprint.  We had 3 antipasta i.e the octopus, asparagus and the burratina  and they were all wonderful.  Octopus nicely grilled and well seasoned with a wonderful charr. asparagus simple yet tasting the freshness of it and of course the creamy burrata.  The pastas were also wonderfully done al dente and tasted wonderful.  We finished off with wonderful desserts tiramisu (not the best) and profiterole.  So really a unpretentious place for a nice simple Italian as long u come early - 5:30pm for the parking.   Mar 28th '18Back again.  Glad to report food & service as good as ever the only issue again was the parking.  The shark parking summon people just circling waiting to strike at you :).  Now what is really surprising is the napoleon pizza is even better than the one we had in Napoli!!!

Based on rave reviews about the brick-oven pizza, I finally got a chance to visit Cicheti. You should definitely call to make a reservation, which can get difficult if you're looking to come at a peak time on the weekends.I came with a friend and shared a Pollo (almond pesto chicken) Pizza as well as a Squid Ink pasta (with crab meat). Both dishes were excellent, well-portioned and a great combination for sharing. I would say that the only thing to make the dinner more excellent is if the Pizza had been hotter when it was served. I've been to restaurants where the brick oven pizza is so fresh that it hurts to hold it in my hand (ie: Alt Pizza at Suntec). For a party of 2 on a Friday night, the bill came out to just over $60 including 10% service charge and GST. Not bad, but considering how busy this place seems to get over the weekends, I think I still prefer to go to Alt for my Pizza!

Came here for my sister's bday dinner but she left disappointed. We had chosen to dine at cicheti because she wanted to satisfy her craving of having squid ink pasta and google proved aforementioned restaurant to have one of the better squid ink dishes. Our family got the pulpo and burratina to share as appetizers. The pulpo was way too salty and over cooked - it was really tough. The burratina was 'weak,' for lack of a better word - it was hardly even creamy and more watery than anything. As our mains, we got 2 seafood stews (which tasted decent), a Bismark pizza and the tonnareli nero. My mom complained that the pizza was way overpriced since it came with such basic ingredients. And for the pasta, it was too salty for my sister's liking. She returned it back to the kitchen and the chefs willingly cooked up another portion for her - but it still came out salty the 2nd time around. Maybe the water used to boil the pasta was way over salted? Maybe the pasta itself was made too salty in the kitchen because it's supposedly homemade? I don't know...The kitchen kindly gave us a complimentary dessert (chocolate cake) to make up for all the problems so that was nice of them. But overall, it wasn't a very satisfying meal. We wouldn't come back.

Real food. Period. This is one of the best Italian restaurants in Singapore, as told by many before me. They have a wood-fired oven that makes the pizza really authentic and just so fresh. Everything we've ordered was excellent. I'm a huge fan of those places where their integrity in food shows through from the bread they serve on the side -- they were so well-baked to be crips on the surface and textured just right on the inside. I've had the prawns (4/5) for appetizer -- again very fresh and loved the bread on the side. (good food just don't require much words.) Carbonara pizza (5/5)--excellent, excellent, excellent. I definitely would agree that pizzas are Cicheti's greatest strength. Despite the misconception that carbonara is some creamy, alfredo-like saucy anything, this was an authentic carbonara creation with egg in the middle with caramelized onion that complemented the rich pizza so well. Gnocchi (3/5) on the other hand, was a bit dull. It was good, but not to the standard that was shown through with pizza and the appetizer. I really liked the ricotta bits that were dropped on gnocchi but that was about it. Nothing spectacular. Panna cotta (5/5) -- THE best I've had in Singapore. Generous portion of really well-made panna cottaChocolate fondant (2/5) -- disappointing. Just overly sweet without much sophistication. Would not recommend. Service was okay. I've been told that I wouldn't be able to grab a seat as a walk-in that easily. So I did make the reservation. However, they really need to work on the speed. I am not talking about the slowness in general (as I do understand that good food can take some time) but the interval at which they brought us our food just left us in a very awkward eating & stopping cycle that did not create a good meal experience.All in all, pizza was super impressive and I loved the restaurant. Will definitely be back.

A very cozy restaurant serving Italian food located in the city. I noticed that they have a traditional woodfire oven but we didn't order any of the pizza. Instead, we ordered their daily specials, vongole and roasted veal. The vongoles was nicely cooked with white wine and garlic (not spaghetti), fresh and fragrant. And the veal was perfectly cooked at medium rare paired with Brussels sprouts and bacon. My friend and I love this dish. Price wise, the final bill was $80. Not really cheap but considered the food quality and the good service, worth it. Next time, I will try their pasta and pizza.

If you're craving authentic Italian pizza from a wood fire oven, Cicheti will be your place. This cosy spot has an unassuming shop front on Kandahar St and you could even pass by it if you're not looking for the shop number. Once you enter, you're transported into some (fancy) hole in the wall Italian spot with some legit offerings.I had the margherita bufala, and after looking at all the Yelp photos post-meal, I realised it's a very popular choice! As bufala mozzarella is a soft cheese, it did make the pizza slightly watery, but the tomato sauce and chewy, slightly charred crust made up for it. Not sure if I was just hungry or if it was just THAT good, but I was able to eat the entire pizza myself. I noticed other people were splitting their pies, haha.

I was ecstatic to find this little gem in a country where truly great non-Asian cuisine is hard to come by. I've had the pleasure of trying the pizza, the clam pasta, as well as the prawn starter plate, and all the dishes exceeded my expectations. Absolutely delicious and the staff is friendly to boot. Unfortunately, this doesn't cut it as a 5 stars only because of the wait/reservation system. As one other reviewer noted, even when making a reservation, they basically say you have to be out of the restaurant by a certain time and make it a point to re-emphasize the fact while you're there. While this might be a cultural norm in Singapore, I find that incredibly off putting. It's like, hey, I'm a paying customer too. But I'll be back, because their pizza is bomb.com

Why didn't I know this place earlier? This is to me, a perfect Saturdate venue for a new couple trying out good food! The ambience is warm, inviting yet casual.  We had Polpo, the grilled octopus tail as a starter and it tastes delicious. It is a special menu for the day, thus look out for it! We ordered the Margarita Bulfala as I see that many people have ordered and raved about it. I like the fact that is a stone fired oven pizza. It is also fun to watch the Chef making the dough and putting the pizza toppings. Lastly, we had the squid ink tagliatelle with crab meats. It is actually tomato sauce, not black squid ink sauce, just so you know what to expect. Service was good. Nothing to complain about. There is a good selection of red and white wine. No draught beer though. I will be back for sure!
The best pizza of Singapore. Consistently. Small venue, too bad they are closed on Sunday...

I absolutely adore this place! I came here as one of the first guests last year right after it opened and I immediately felt in love with it and so did my friends whom I invited afterwards. This place is great in every single aspect you can think of. The location in the Arab Street is very convenient, the ambiance is very friendly, staff is super friendly and polite and the food is just awesome! I can highly recommend their pizzas. It is great to come here with a group of friends and order various items from the menu to be shared. The prices are very reasonable and as such it is a great choice!

Good service, good food and ambience.  What more can you ask for really?  Only issue with this place is as per any restaurant in this area - parking which can get rather frustrating circulating and increasing your carbon footprint.  We had 3 antipasta i.e the octopus, asparagus and the burratina  and they were all wonderful.  Octopus nicely grilled and well seasoned with a wonderful charr. asparagus simple yet tasting the freshness of it and of course the creamy burrata.  The pastas were also wonderfully done al dente and tasted wonderful.  We finished off with wonderful desserts tiramisu (not the best) and profiterole.  So really a unpretentious place for a nice simple Italian as long u come early - 5:30pm for the parking.   Mar 28th '18Back again.  Glad to report food & service as good as ever the only issue again was the parking.  The shark parking summon people just circling waiting to strike at you :).  Now what is really surprising is the napoleon pizza is even better than the one we had in Napoli!!!

It is great to come here with a group of friends and order various items from the menu to be shared. The prices are very reasonable and as such it is a great choice!

Really good wood oven pizza and in all honesty even better than where the pizza chef used to work (** have tp find out yourself )  the little dishes are just ok.! love the decor of this little place too. recommended.

Very nice cozy place with amazing food. Every dish was great! Pizzas fresh from the oven, pasta homemade and al dente.. the beef cheek ravioli (?) with truffle was amazing! And you know a restaurant is doing things right when a person who doesn't eat octopus (me) actually loved their octopus. Surprisingly soft and tender, very well done!

The decor and ambiance is outstanding. High quality, but not overdone. Very comfortable, antique style with a few outdoor tables.Food is also top notch. One of the best Neapolitan style pizzas I've had (and I've had many, it's an obsession of mine). I had the bufala margarita, the dough was perfectly cooked in the wood fired oven, which is visible and also adds to the ambiance.

Superb quality pizzas! They have the oven and definitely the chef to impress everyone who goes there for a meal. Food is reasonably priced, and the menu is long enough to order any quality Italian dish. Don't forget to order the chocolate lava cake for dessert! Its outstanding

The pizza is fantastic, and most probably my new favourite pizza in Singapore beating out previous faves Extra Virgin and Limoncello. The pasta also is simply wonderful: proper al dente, hand-made especially for the restaurant (according to front-of-house) with a delicately put-together sauce (the pappardelle ragu in this case) and no scrimping on quality ingredients.Moreover the price point is really quite brilliant. Approx. $70 for two pastas and a pizza. I'm not saying it's a steal but given the trend of skyrocketing prices these days, it's pretty damn great. The pizzas themselves are under $20 which is already cheaper than the two previous favourites I mentioned.What let this place down are some details. Firstly, the pizza came out incredibly quickly and was lukewarm. I suspect it was prepared earlier for another patron. The fact that I still rate it so highly is a testament to its overall quality but the misstep still deserves mention.The other letdown was the service. It wasn't terrible. Front of house (a European chap) served us the entire time. He was affable and fairly attentive. But i walked in at 8pm hoping to secure a table and was told that none were available until 9pm. I saw several free, assumed they were booked, agreed to come back for 9 and requested a call should any table free up earlier.My request was rebuffed. I was told that the restaurant was "short-staffed" and that front of house simply did not have time to check his reservations. This is not good enough. Staff your restaurant properly. When I returned at ten to nine, sure enough, the same tables that were available earlier were still empty. Something tells me no one ever ended up taking them and I could have well eaten earlier. This lack of attention and care for your customer is disappointing.The moral of this story: book ahead at Cicheti and accept some arrogance - the place is clearly buzzy right now. But the quality of the food is well worth turning a blind eye to the flaws.
Love on a plate. The menu's small but the delight is bountiful. One of our favourite date night venues for great pizzas and good wines!

Hands down the best pizza I've had in Singapore. The wood fired oven makes all the difference, and the crust comes out thin but not cracker-y, maintaining that chewiness and blistering I've been searching for in Singapore for a while. Toppings are minimal and classic. For SF-ers, most comparable to Delfina or Delarosa. The pastas are also very good because they are noticeably house-made, and whatever "cicheti" or small plates they have on special are a good bet. It's a small space so you're better off calling for a reservation and going during the week. Service is above average, with waiters keeping an eye on you, refilling wine glasses and sincerely in support of the menu items they recommend.

Some restaurants deserve reviews, and others like Cicheti deserve love letters. Cicheti is my new favorite pizza in Singapore. They impress me, which is hard to do given my probably unreasonably high standards for pizza. We have gone here once a week for the past month. Here's why:The mozzarella was fresh and perfect on both the salad and the pizza. The vegetables were all fresh. The char on the crust was there but not excessive. The Cioppino has so much seafood in it that I wonder how they can make a profit off of it. The tagliatelle carne is probably better than you would get in most restaurants in Rome. The gelato is very flavorful and the polenta cake pairs well with it.The only somewhat reasonable competition I know of in terms of Napoli-style (i.e. the best style) pizza is Operetta. I think Cicheti has a better ambiance than Operetta. While the quality of the ingredients are probably equivalent, Cicheti has better execution. The toppings were more evenly spread out on the pizza. The salad was also slightly larger. Cicheti is also cheaper than most other pizza places in Singapore, in part because they don't charge GST (yet?). It's a weird feeling to come here and get a salad, a pizza, a pasta, and the Cioppino for 90 SGD total. Comparing that to Operetta, which is nonetheless a great restaurant, it's like getting one of those dishes for free.If I were to think of anything to dock points for, it would be that their upstairs seating area is so cold that it gives me a headache. Lately we have been calling and asking to sit downstairs or outside and they have been accommodating.All-in-all, this is a rare Italian restaurant in Singapore that doesn't seem like mostly a cash-grab. They seem to care about the details, making great food with authentic ingredients, and making people happy.

I really like the food here. I have always been looking for authentic non-pretentious Italian fare in Singapore, and I have to say, this quite hits the spot. I had both the uni pasta (a special, and not always on the menu) and the scallop and prawn capellini, and they were both excellent. The home-made capellini soaked in the saffron sauce completely, and it was a very well-balanced delicate sauce that I totally love. This place is good, and they have the hoards and hoards of patrons to prove it. Will definitely be back!
My favourite pizza place in Singapore. Tried Bismarck diabola margarita pizzas, all superb! Squid ink and vongole also really nice. I gave big thumbs up for the chef. He gave me a big smile!

Although the food is quite pricey, this is probably my favorite restaurant in Singapore The baked pumpkin, gnocchi with truffle &Pappardell al Ragu were amazing, we'd rate them a 9/10.The sparkling wine were also good.The pizzas were just average, not the best pizza in town.The service here is pretty good.The location is a little bit hard to find as they do not any huge sign at the frontThe best highlight of our dinner was the dessert, the panna cotta was a lot better than what we expected.Lava cake and the tiramisu were also a 9/10!

Food: 8/10. Fresh ingredients, bread baked daily, pastas and pizzas made from scratch.   Ambiance: 7/10. Casual and elegant. I will be back to check out the bar and patio seating on the second floor.Price: 10/10. Where else can you get a beer/wine for $10 and dinner plates for $15 for the quality and in this setting?

We went for dinner to Cicheti as a party of 4 adults. The table was reserved on Monday evening at 6.30pm for dinner at 7.30pm on the same night. On arriving at the restaurant, my mum and I reached first and were shown to a high table meant for 6 people. We requested for a table with low seating since my mum has pain in her knees, so is unable to climb/ step up and sit comfortably. This was the start of the rudeness by the manager. He flatly refused to even make any attempt to accommodate us on any other table, saying that the place was fully booked (we were seated at the 3rd occupied table on the lower floor where there were 3 more tables empty at the time). So we adjusted and ordered our meal since we wanted to have a peaceful dinner. Midway through the meal my mum switched to the extra (till them empty) seat since I had ordered prawns and the smell was too strong and bothered her (she is vegetarian, and not a fan of seafood smell). Back came the manager to tell her off !!! We told him that she would switch back to her seat if any other guests showed up. That wasn't good enough for him, so instead of creating a hue and cry my mum simply sat back on the original seat.This is when I requested the manager to have a chat with me and then started his racist rant against Indians :(Some quotes from our conversation - things actually said by the Cicheti Manager to me: "There is always problems with Indians only, they agree on the phone and then want something different when they come""I hate Indians""There are many other Italian restaurants, why don't you go there"We finished the food we had ordered till then, paid our bill, refused to pay the 10% service charge and left!We have lived in Singapore for nearly a decade now and also travelled extensively abroad. We have never faced such racist behaviour from people on the front line in the service industry. So appalled and disturbed by this experience that I felt compelled to share it in such great detail. I also saw that we are not the first to be spoken down to by the manager, there are some other reviews for the restaurant which say the same thing - the food is great, but the manager is awful and rude !

The service was absolutely spot-on (which is a big deal in Singapore!) and the food was downright amazing. Pizza crust was cooked to perfection and the deserts were divine (the panna cotta was perfect). Lovely atmosphere, family friendly although not teeming with crying babies.

Had a good time until the last minute. Towards to the end, the general manager came in rude attitude to push us to leave in five mins altogether we still had one glass of wine to finish each. We were not communicated earlier with closing. This is the worst service ever I had in Singapore. Would not recommend to anyone..

Great place ruined by the service level. In fact, it was the GM, Ravi who ruined it for us. It was a great night until he tried to "chase" us away by accusing us of drinking too slow; 2mins before his staff told us it's ok, we can take our time and asked nicely that we try to finish it in the next 30mins because they are closing (1st notification). Ravi told us shortly that we only have 5mins to leave (when we both had a full glass of wine) in the most abrasive attitude that I have ever encountered and invited us to leave a comment because he is the GM and co-owner of the restaurant. The food was not too bad to be fair but not good enough to want to come back to this arrogance. There are too many great options in Singapore to bother abt this place.

4 stars for the food and 2 stars for the service.We came here for lunch quite early at 12.15pm. Ordered the burratina for starters and 3 pizzas (diavola, bismark and prosciutto) for four and everything was quite delicious. The burratina cheese was fresh, cuddled by some rucola and delicious sweet onion bulbs. All 3 pizzas were perfectly done though I personally preferred the diavola and bismark.Unfortunately what dragged our meal down was the service. Despite being one of the earlier tables, boy did the food take forever to appear. Our starter took at least 20 minutes to be served despite most of the ingredients being raw. Our first pizza arrived about 20 minutes after that and then we waited again for the last two.We had to keep asking the servers to top up our water (every other table seemed to have a bottle of water except ours), provide serving cutlery for every dish (we stated we were sharing the food), check on our food...it just became painful after awhile. I don't think I've ever dreaded going back to restaurant that serves good food but I actually am. I think the front of house staff did the best they could but perhaps some smarter managemenet is needed - provide a bucket of cutlery on each table and flasks of water, have someone help the pizza guy (there was one guy flipping pizzas and 2-3 in the back with waitresses occasionally stepping in) and perhaps trim the menu if it expedites the lunch service.

Although the food was good, it was not 'wow' quality as I expected based on other reviews. The burratina was not available that day so we went with two starters which were the day specials. The grilled octopus was excellent and on point but the beef ravioli with burnt butter sauce was a disaster. The pasta was too thick and the filling was tasteless. For mains, we had a lamb ragout pappardelle and a squid ink pasta. The pappardelle was good, with the pasta having good consistency and bite. Unfortunately, the squid ink pasta (linguine) was also too thick and lent a strange texture to the otherwise well-executed sauce. Dessert (chocolate lava cake) was excellent. Service was so-so. May be back for the famed pizzas next time.

Among the best Italian food you can find in Singapore. My wife and I haven't had better. Last night was our second visit to Cicheti and it won't be our last.The positives: the food is terrific. My wife and I started with an Arugula and Pear Salad that had some roasted almonds, a balsamic glaze and a hint of goat cheese. Beautiful presentation...not the best tasting or best looking salad on the menu, but very good. We ordered a margarita with bufala mozzarella pizza as an appetizer...second time having this, terrific crust, a little under done but the mozzarella kills it, best pizza I've had in Singapore, hands down. I then ordered the paparedelle and lamb Raghu while my wife had the tagliatelle and squid ink pasta...both terrific, would have again, no questions asked.The negatives: they sat us right next to the door and they kept the door open. This is a problem because if you've been to Singapore before, it tends to be a little hot. I made the reservation 48 hours in advance, and they wouldn't move us away from the doorway, even though we were the first ones in the restaurant (1 star for service staff etiquette). Drinks/beer selection is ok...nothing special.Cicheti is great. The staff could use some polishing. Otherwise, love it and will be back

This Mexican restaurant is at the head of Haji Lane, and that lends half the charm. There's live music and an under-lit ambiance. The nachos & guac was very average, but the main course quesedilla and enchiladas were full of flavour. The service was quick and efficient.
Pretty good Mexican food (for Singapore) and a decent happy hour. There is live music at night, great atmosphere and the staff is attentive and friendly. Salud!!!

Five stars for affordable happy hour margaritas. Five stars for great murals. But the food isn't worth it (not surprising, as it is just about as far away from Mexico as you can get). I'd recommend it if you're just looking for a nice spot to post up and drink a slushee marg while you watch the tourists go by. But go just about anywhere else in the neighborhood for your dinner.
Very Good food, best in the street, but service so bad: lazy people, food takes a Lot of time to arrive. The waiter esmoking infront of you and using mobile phone all the time

As a native Southern Californian, I have tried to eat only cultural foods while in Asia until I returned to the warm bosom of Mexican food back home. But I had to have my Margarita fix and this place went far beyond my expectations! Great atmosphere and the esquites were exquisite!
I'm a big fan of this place. The ceviche is excellent and the portions are pretty generous. I've eaten here only a couple of times, but it's been consistentIy good.  really love the relaxed vibe.

Love this place. Nice mexican/american food, in lovely Haji Lane, at a great price. Beers are super cheap (for Singapore standards), and all the dishes I've tried have been very good. I love the terrace and the atmosphere in this place.Order the nachos w/guacamole, which is done at your table right in front of you.

Great location on Haji Ln, right next to live music! I can only speak to the smoothies I got--they were really fresh and flavorful, but a little on the pricey end. Nevertheless, a cool spot to check out on Friday or Saturday nights!

Margaritas and Tacos, also super delicious Pico de Gallo... Our neighbor compares this place to Yucatan and Acapulco, sooo epic!Fresh mixed Guacamole at our table, attentive nice staff - a lively place - just right.We will be definitely back around here!

Amazing ambience! Great outdoor tables on the street and surrounded by other bars so you can drink at more than one place. Love the happy hour drinks and is busy usually at that time. Recommend the  nachos and enchiladas for food!

A massive building with multiple entrances, practically spanning the whole block between Haji Lane, Bali Lane, Beach Rd. and the alley that becomes Baghdad St. No way to miss it, just look for people taking selfies beside a kitsch "Mayan" mural on Haji Lane.Having read the menu before, our expectations were very high. When we eventually visited Piedra Negra, my wife and I had a more than decent guacamole to start. We tried the lentil soup which is fabulous, tasty, simple and with a certain home-made quality. Our expectations went higher. While Diana had some really good chicken enchiladas made with a very hot and tasty green sauce, I asked for a lamb mixiote which turned out to be quite disappointing (expectations crashing down here). I need to explain: mixiotes are meat stews wrapped in the outer skin of maguey (century plant) leaves, or in aluminium foil or baking paper. The fact that I was given a stew inside a cute iron pot instead of wrapped in paper  means our pals at Piedra Negra don't understand what the dish is about. To be fair, the stew itself was delicious with the soft lamb melting in my mouth, worthy of a good Irish or Czech restaurant.The drinks menu has a decent assortment of tequilas, and a few Mexican beers, served with lime wedges just like everywhere, except in México. They have a single brand of mezcal, but it's the good stuff (I even got the worm for myself). Piedra Negra is a fun, lively place with salsa music, tasty food and a colourful, albeit kitsch environment. It's a pity they sell themselves as a Mexican restaurant. The fact that they put so much effort in looking Mexican rather than cooking Mexican ends up reinforcing stereotypes, instead of undermining them.Curious fact: the Mexican Embassy, ironically, is across the street.

This is a great, funky little spot. I recently had a girls' night out here and it was fantastic. 4 of us shared the guacamole, delicious and made at your table, and the jalapeño poppers, spicy so watch out! Both were great dishes. I had the pork tacos which were pretty good. The pork itself was a bit bland, and there was too much, but there was spicy sauce and pickled onion to give it a bit of a kick. The tortillas were excellent. I must admit I can't remember what everyone else had as we had too many cocktails... I do know that everyone was happy with their choices! The mojitos and frozen margaritas were too tasty! It was good value for money as 2 starters, 4 mains and 12 cocktails came to about $80 a head which is pretty decent for this town. I will definitely be heading back at some point.

Decent place with a good ambience. Food was passable - have had much better Mexican cuisine elsewhere. Service was good on a busy night. The highlight was the guacamole which was assembled table side - unfortunately the portion was a bit on the stingy side

Piedra Negra- yes, five stars. California girl reporting in.....love this place.* star- Food:fresh, fresh ingredients. Excellent flavors. Beautiful presentation. Ordered a variety of tacos and table side prepared guacamole with freshly made chips. Loved all the herbs, spices and sauces that you could add to accommodate your palate. Again very F-R-E-S-H! Live in Cali, traveled to Mexico countless times, Central American mother-in-law. This is good food...Trust!* star- Staff: knowledgeable, helpful, professional. Although it was a very busy night we were seated quickly. Staff very attentive through the evening. * star- Restaurant: Art, art, art. cool Mexican murals cover the walls inside and outside. Reminds me of Lucky Street in San Francisco's Mission Dist.  lots of different seating options...Out, in, in-between. Bar, restaurant...etc. it's all good.* star- Location: cool area, a cool "scene" Just really great for people watching. *star- good South of the Cali border drink menu...I had Awesome Margaritas. Option of pitcher or single glass, cubed ice or blended ice. This restaurant is COOL people. Check it out!

In Texas after a fun night of drinking and bar hopping, one usually stops at Taco Bell for "fourth meal." Unfortunately, Singapore does not have Taco Bell, but they do have Piedra Negra. We were out last night and before grabbing our cab to go home, we stopped at Piedra Negra. We got a table outside. Our waitress was prompt and friendly. My husband and I split a beef burrito which came with delicious waffle fries. Our friends split nachos. Now can you really compare it to Texas Tex Mex or California Mexican food? Probably not, but you are in Singapore. Honestly, we thought it was delicious, the prices were reasonable and we'll be back!

Great vibe on a great street!  We only drank when we visited but the food looked and smelled delicious.  The setting is great for upbeat Friday or Saturday socializing and I'd love to return to try the food at some point!

2.5 stars.  ok, so i wouldn't come here expecting a "mexican" joint, but the food is decent if you take it for what it's worth.  first of all, all of the starters were more spanish as opposed to mexican.  there's no tortilla espanola or patatas bravas in mexican cuisine, nor is there ceviche, which is south american.either way, we got a bunch of apps to share, and i got the cod w/ potato mash and salad as my main.  it was definitely more american as opposed to mexican.if you wash down all the food w/ some margaritas, you will forget that you are not dining at a real mexican restaurant.  also, if you come w/ great company like i did, you will have a fun time.

Love this place! As an American craving some serious Tex Mex while in Singapore, this place hit the spot. The guac was amazing, not to mention our awesome server made it table side. Frozen margs in 90 weather? Yes please. I would recommend this to all friends and colleagues in the Singapore area. Thanks for everything, Piedra Negra!

I don't understand why this place has any bad reviews.. It's so delicious and they have great service! They make guacamole table side and it was so delicious. Our sever was super friendly and even let us use multiple credit cards to pay our bill. If you are looking for Mexican food in Singapore I would definitely recommend. WITH LOVE FROM CHICAGO USA !

I warned myself before coming here--braced myself and held my breath until my face turned red. But, alas! My local friend insisted and told me that her expat friends liked, yadda, yadda. Fine, fine...I've tried Piedra Negra's nachos before and their margaritas are pretty solid so why not just try a fish taco? Big mistake. The food here is horrendous. Nothing comparable to Mexican in California or TexMex in Chevys. After living in Singapore for the past three years, my expectations were LOW. Their baja fish taco tasted like sandpaper. The batter used to fry the fish was too thick and the fish was not fresh.As a prime establishment in Arab St., Piedra Negra simply needs to do better. With the new food culture popping up in Singapore (and the new array of Mexican restaurants), this one is a big thumbs down.

Piedra Negra- yes, five stars. California girl reporting in.....love this place.* star- Food:fresh, fresh ingredients. Excellent flavors. Beautiful presentation. Ordered a variety of tacos and table side prepared guacamole with freshly made chips. Loved all the herbs, spices and sauces that you could add to accommodate your palate. Again very F-R-E-S-H! Live in Cali, traveled to Mexico countless times, Central American mother-in-law. This is good food...Trust!* star- Staff: knowledgeable, helpful, professional. Although it was a very busy night we were seated quickly. Staff very attentive through the evening. * star- Restaurant: Art, art, art. cool Mexican murals cover the walls inside and outside. Reminds me of Lucky Street in San Francisco's Mission Dist.  lots of different seating options...Out, in, in-between. Bar, restaurant...etc. it's all good.* star- Location: cool area, a cool "scene" Just really great for people watching. *star- good South of the Cali border drink menu...I had Awesome Margaritas. Option of pitcher or single glass, cubed ice or blended ice. This restaurant is COOL people. Check it out!

I had seen this place several times in passing but had never ventured in so when a friend suggested meeting here for dinner and drinks I decided it was a good time to try it out. I was wrong. When we arrived it had already gotten busy and we were placed in a table in the alley. We had a large group (7 in total) and were all huddled around one table. There was so little room some members of our group had to place their plates in their lap to eat. There was a large open table close to the restaurant but we were told it was reserved. They held that table open for over an hour (no exaggeration) while we were left to dodge cars driving through the alley and eat out of our laps. The food was also nothing spectacular. My chicken quesadilla was decent but the thing they called a taco was more like an oversized taquito. It was a tortilla stuffed with meat and then rolled up and fried. It tasted okay but was not what we were expecting. The bright spot of the experience were the margaritas. We had a pitcher of strawberry and a pitcher of the original and they were both very tasty.The service staff was definitely overwhelmed; the restaurant is large and it was completely full. It did not seem like there were enough people working to adequately cover the needs of the restaurant and they were disorganized. All in all, next time I find myself wandering Haji lane and see this place, I will keep walking.

This is a great, funky little spot. I recently had a girls' night out here and it was fantastic. 4 of us shared the guacamole, delicious and made at your table, and the jalapeño poppers, spicy so watch out! Both were great dishes. I had the pork tacos which were pretty good. The pork itself was a bit bland, and there was too much, but there was spicy sauce and pickled onion to give it a bit of a kick. The tortillas were excellent. I must admit I can't remember what everyone else had as we had too many cocktails... I do know that everyone was happy with their choices! The mojitos and frozen margaritas were too tasty! It was good value for money as 2 starters, 4 mains and 12 cocktails came to about $80 a head which is pretty decent for this town. I will definitely be heading back at some point.

Amazing ambience! Great outdoor tables on the street and surrounded by other bars so you can drink at more than one place. Love the happy hour drinks and is busy usually at that time. Recommend the  nachos and enchiladas for food!

We like this place. We've lived in San Diego and constantly miss Mexican.  This is one of the cheaper Mexican places we've found, and it "kind of" hits the spot.The guacamole is a great deal and the chips are freshly fried. The steak was tender and juicy, and a good deal for the price, but it's not "Mexican". We also got the burrito, and the shredded beef is authentic. But they didn't add sour cream and guacamole.What I wish they had was a Super Burrito -- the burritos where you can get meat, beans, rice, salsa, sour cream, cheese, guacamole all rolled in a big burrito.  They don't have that here -- it's a different kind of Mexican. Prices are inexpensive for what you're getting -- we will definitely be going back.

2.5 stars.  ok, so i wouldn't come here expecting a "mexican" joint, but the food is decent if you take it for what it's worth.  first of all, all of the starters were more spanish as opposed to mexican.  there's no tortilla espanola or patatas bravas in mexican cuisine, nor is there ceviche, which is south american.either way, we got a bunch of apps to share, and i got the cod w/ potato mash and salad as my main.  it was definitely more american as opposed to mexican.if you wash down all the food w/ some margaritas, you will forget that you are not dining at a real mexican restaurant.  also, if you come w/ great company like i did, you will have a fun time.

Love this place! As an American craving some serious Tex Mex while in Singapore, this place hit the spot. The guac was amazing, not to mention our awesome server made it table side. Frozen margs in 90 weather? Yes please. I would recommend this to all friends and colleagues in the Singapore area. Thanks for everything, Piedra Negra!

Singapore as a whole does not have amazing Mexican food, so if you are craving for some - this is probably one of the better places to go. The Quesadilla's, Nachos and Ceviche are great, but not sure about the rest of the menu.What IS amazing though, are the different kind of Margaritas they have. Shaken or blended, both are great. They also sell them in pitchers, and aren't stingy with the tequila. Share a jug between two people and it's quite enough to make you happy campers if you aren't eating anything.What I like about this place is the quirky decor and also the ambience it has. It's a great place to hang out with friends to have a few beverages and just chill out. It's always busy on Friday nights and weekends so if you are planning on catching up with friends, do make reservations. Overall, a great place to chill out with friends.

This is a great place for drinking and people watching. If you r expecting authentic chicken mole or carna asada, you will be disappointed. Highly recommended for a friendly crowd and live music in Haji Lane.

I'm not crazy about the food here -- I think it's okay to quite good, but I would never come out of my way to dine here. It's not that it's bad, it's just that it's not... awesome.BUTI am a fan of Piedra Negra for many other reasons. I love the live music at the alley outside, on Fridays and weekends. I love the weird decor of the place. The casual sitting/standing along the alley and the wonderful friends I have made from just standing around watching random musicians. I love that people sometimes spontaneously burst into song and dance as they walk by (true story, and happens quite often) because the vibe at Piedra Negra (at least on the outside) is so energetic and contagious.A typical Friday or Saturday night for me would be a couple of drinks (on the street, yes) at Piedra Negra, then walking down the street to Om for other types of awesome experiences and people. It's hard to explain. But I do love it.

I am not sure why some people have rated this place so high. It is really not that great at all. Sure the vibe and ambience is nice. Its right in the happening Haji Lane and during weekends and night time, its really bustling and a nice energy. However dont we all go to restaurants for the food and not the ambience? Traditional Mexican? Not a chance. The place seems to be confused with their identity. Are they trying to be Mexican or Spanish? Either way, their dishes (whether Spanish or Mexican) are not great. Better to skip this place. You can honestly get better Mexican food at a place like Baja Fresh.

Singapore as a whole does not have amazing Mexican food, so if you are craving for some - this is probably one of the better places to go. The Quesadilla's, Nachos and Ceviche are great, but not sure about the rest of the menu.What IS amazing though, are the different kind of Margaritas they have. Shaken or blended, both are great. They also sell them in pitchers, and aren't stingy with the tequila. Share a jug between two people and it's quite enough to make you happy campers if you aren't eating anything.What I like about this place is the quirky decor and also the ambience it has. It's a great place to hang out with friends to have a few beverages and just chill out. It's always busy on Friday nights and weekends so if you are planning on catching up with friends, do make reservations. Overall, a great place to chill out with friends.

I heard great things about this Mexican restaurant's authenticity, but if this is authentic Mexican food, I am really not a fan.  The food is at best average. I must say, however, that the Strawberry Margherita was delicious and that proved to be the highlight of our meal. It came in a generously sized jug that could be shared amongst many. There are better Mexican spots out there, but if you insist on visiting (because, well, the location is great, and I did love the quirky decorative elements like the skeleton dolls), take note to avoid sitting by the main road. The sounds of traffic will compete with, and beat, whatever conversation you are attempting to have, and there are stagnant smells coming from the drains. Instead, walk down the small alley and try to get a table at the back.

Really really good nachos and margaritas. Piedra Negra is one of those places where I could come and get the same thing over and over again because its just that good! Probably the best nachos I've had in Singapore so far.But beyond that... there's not much else. The rest of the menu is quite standard, Quesadilla's and such, which to be honest, do not taste that great.I hear the ceviche is also quite good but I've never tried it myself.The decor however is quite unique, both inside and out. The graffiti-esque art outside is unlike anything else in the Arab Street area and makes the perfect entrance to the hipstery Haji Lane. To add to it, the street is adorned with surprisingly talented musicians on a weekend night to set the mood.Go there for the nachos, stay for the atmosphere.

I'm not crazy about the food here -- I think it's okay to quite good, but I would never come out of my way to dine here. It's not that it's bad, it's just that it's not... awesome.BUTI am a fan of Piedra Negra for many other reasons. I love the live music at the alley outside, on Fridays and weekends. I love the weird decor of the place. The casual sitting/standing along the alley and the wonderful friends I have made from just standing around watching random musicians. I love that people sometimes spontaneously burst into song and dance as they walk by (true story, and happens quite often) because the vibe at Piedra Negra (at least on the outside) is so energetic and contagious.A typical Friday or Saturday night for me would be a couple of drinks (on the street, yes) at Piedra Negra, then walking down the street to Om for other types of awesome experiences and people. It's hard to explain. But I do love it.

There are not many Mexican restaurants in Singapore (only 2 that I know of) and as a fan of Tex-Mex, I was thrilled to find this gem of a place at the end of Haji Lane. The murals are in your face - very artistic, and the establishments boasts a cool band that plays Mexican classics and traditional songs.What I Love: The ambiance, the food and drinks are great. The food is authentic, and portions are pretty okay. They could be bigger though. But comparing it to American portions may not be fair either. The margaritas are my fave - and getting a a whole pitcher is more affordable. The Burrito, Nachos and Tapas are sure bets. MUST HAVE: The Salmon-Avacado Ceviche salad served in a big martini glass. Yummmmmmm.What I Don't Love: The prices. The prices are pretty steep.... Drinks and 2 mains, plus 2 starters will set you back $100, at least.

This 12 dish prix fixe menu is a mystery to be solved by your sense of taste, smell, and feel. Plan 2 hours for the experience. Make a reservation in advance.  Peek busy time was 7-8:30pm.  We pretty much had the room to ourselves from 6pm-6:30pm on a Thursday night.After being seated in the cocktail lounge and offered the cocktail menu and drink options for the meal, we were led by our visually impaired host up stairs and into the darkness where we were introduced to navigating our table and meal without being able to see any of it.I surprised myself by ignoring the cutlery and wanting to touch a lot of the food in the dark to better understand what it was.  No one around me could see me anyway- so why not play with my food?! Tasty food and a unique experience that builds greater textural food wisdom and provides an introduction to navigating life with out sight.I learned how important it was to hear someone's presence in the room (clicking sounds were often used to designate someone nearby)- to understand where they are and when they are moving, or close, or far away.The total damage to the wallet was about $330 at the end of it all.  Here's what we had:2 Pre-Dinner Signature Cocktails $402 Prix Fixe Dinners $1802 Mocktail Pairings (3 each) $601 Bottle of Sparkling Water $8In retrospect, I felt the mocktails were far too sweet, and not paired very well to the variety of dishes.  So if I came back, I might just get one cocktail downstairs to bring up to the meal with me and then just have sparkling water during the meal to really help the food flavors stand out.  If the mocktails had been more interesting and less like a blanket of sweet-juice over my pallet, it would have felt more worthy of adding to the meal.

A very unique dining experience. As the name suggests, you dine in absolute pitch darkness. It is fun but takes some time getting used to. But literally its so dark you cannot see your own hands let alone the person in front of you.All the staff are visually impaired, so I really applaud the social initiative. They server 3 courses, with 4 dishes per course. At the end they ask you to guess what you had based on your sense of taste and touch. We got most of the things wrong!!Just to set the stage, the food will not blow your mind, but you don't go here for the food, you go for the experience, which you should definitely try once!

Absolutely the COOLEST dining experience I have ever had! I had to take anxiety medication because I get claustrophobic (and I'm glad I did)! This restaurant is 100% pitch black, you cannot see anything, not even your hand if you put it in front on your eyes. You do not know the food you will eat which makes the experience so much better (not to mention, everything was delicious). I love that they hire people who are partial or completely blind. Our waitress was so incredibly nice and everyone made us feel at ease. I love this place and I can't wait to visit when I go to Singapore again.

Dining in the Dark... would I do it again? Probably not. However, the experience was interesting. Being forced to sit in the dark allowing your others senses to come to the forefront since you are eating in complete darkness was an experience like none other. Now with that being said, the food was eh. The best part of the food was trying to guess what you ate. However, I maybe only actually finished 3 dishes out of the 12 they serve you. Would I do this again next time I'm in Singapore? Probably not, but I will say that if you have the spare time and the extra funds (cost was about $116 Singapore dollars) then why not experience it for yourself.

Very good experience and highly recommended. The food was very tasty and we had fun afterward trying to guess what we ate and drank. Bernard was our waiter, and he was the highlight of the evening with his great sense of humor, impeccable service and his personal experience he was willing to share with us. While it is expensive, it's worth a try!

Have you all dine in the dark before? We all heard a fair bit about the concept of dining in the total darkness, haven't we? I think NOX need no further introduction.NOX is located along the shop houses of beach road occupying 2 level of shop space.The service staff welcomed us into the lounge and gave us a drink menu to choose upon. The moment I sat down, the plushy sofa seat reminds me of Gold Class Cinema lounge, quite similar in a sense. Servers explained there is no food menu to choose from, rather there is a secret menu at $88++ per pax that consists of 12 dishes spreaded into 3 courses, appetizers, mains and desserts. Restaurant menu will be change every 6 - 8 weeks and should you have any dietary preference, e.g. vegetarian, please highlight to them.MocktailA citrus combination of orange with a bittersweet finishing taste from a pomelo. Its more sour than sweet per say with grapefruit, lemon juice, simple syrup and Grenadine that give a tart and sweet flavour to the naturally sour fruit.Grapefruit Spritz - $14The zesty and minty flavours make this quencher such refreshing. Out of 3 drinks tasted, I rate this the best. Ingredients were close to other drinks with passionfruit, simple syrup, lemon juice, lime juice, fresh mint leave and ginger ale.Virgin Passionfruit Julep - $14Being described as not the ordinary strawberry milkshake, it really make me wonder how does it taste like. Drink was milky pink served with little ice cubes and a strawberry. It was more of sweet and less of the sour taste with fresh milk, vanilla syrup, simple syrup, lemon juice and Amaretto Almond Syrup.Strawberry Shaker - $14StartersWe were served with the starters with a vegetarian on the left and 2 mini cones on the right for the non vegetarians. The fried vegetarian had a pleasant scent of truffle oil smell and looks good with its creaming sauce at its base.Starters for the non vegetarian was miniature. Raw salmon was served in the tip of the ice cream cone biscuit added with caviar. The presentation which depicts some plants on the soil had totally taken me away.Before Proceeding into the darknessWe was told not to bring any of our belongings to the dining area and had them kept in the given lockers, not even our handphones or watches with illumination / glow in the dark function. Instagrammers, sorry! For those who needs to go toilet, its best to have the "passage" clear before entering into the darkness.Entering the DarknessWe were quite excited while the door to the dining area swung open and we were greeted by the service staff. Have you wonder how to walk up a flight of steep stairs in total darkness? Well, we conquered the first stage by having 1 hand tapping to each other shoulder in a line and walk up the stair and into the dining.Dining in the darknessIt all started with uneasiness, getting ourselves up at the dining area. When we reached our table, we were led to the back of the chair and have to figure ourselves to take a seat under the clear instructions of course. We were briefed to locate our cutleries (spoon and fork) and the position to place our drinking glass on the table. With every course served, we was told to lean backwards to our chair as these visually impact servers placed the dishes onto our table accurately. Each course consist of 4 dishes served in a wooden tray and placed in a "t" shape.
